nodes.text: A single-kernel, pure-GPU lossy compressor (CUSZP2) can achieve extreme end-to-end throughput and optimized compression ratios while preserving user-bounded data quality for HPC workloads

End-to-end throughput (including all GPU intrinsic APIs and device-level data movement) is the appropriate metric for evaluating GPU lossy compressors because kernel-only throughput can be overly optimistic

CUSZP2 implements compression and decompression entirely within a single GPU kernel using a blockwise 4-stage workflow: lossy conversion, lossless encoding, device-level prefix-sum, and block concatenation

Outlier fixed-length encoding (Outlier-FLE) records per-element sign bits, adaptive fixed-length bit widths, and preserves large outliers in compact bytes; CUSZP2 selects Outlier-FLE per block only when it yields higher compression ratio

Vectorized memory accesses: within-block vector variables (e.g., float4) reduce memory instructions and at block level CUSZP2 arranges warp accesses to adjacent blocks to enable coalescing and maximize global memory bandwidth utilization

Global prefix-sum via decoupled lookback: a compression-aware adaptive lookback lets thread blocks aggregate predecessors while waiting, decoupling the serial chained-scan and hiding device-level synchronization latency

Measured end-to-end throughput on NVIDIA A100 across 9 HPC datasets: average compression 332.42 GB/s and decompression 513.04 GB/s, typically about 2x pure-GPU baselines and ~200x CPU-GPU hybrid compressors

CUSZP2 achieves high memory throughput approaching hardware limits: measured average global memory throughput 1175.34 GB/s (CUSZP2-P) and 1103.45 GB/s (CUSZP2-O) on A100 versus 134–410 GB/s for other pure-GPU compressors

Compression ratio improvements: CUSZP2 with Outlier-FLE (CUSZP2-O) achieves higher compression ratios than state-of-the-art error-bounded GPU compressors in 24 of 27 evaluated cases and notably outperforms baselines for smooth or sparse datasets
Decoupled lookback synchronization yields device-level prefix-sum throughput of 846.85 GB/s on representative datasets, about 2.41x higher than plain chained-scan implementations

CUSZP2 supports double-precision datasets efficiently because lossy conversion maps double-precision values to quantization integers and subsequent lossless steps are unchanged, achieving average compression throughput 612.83–628.54 GB/s and decompression 780.33–809.71 GB/s on evaluated double-precision datasets

CUSZP2 supports random access to block-granularity compressed data by reading stored block offsets and performing device-level synchronization, yielding measured random-access throughput around 1010.07 GB/s on average

CUSZP2 is compatible with lower-end NVIDIA GPUs (RTX 3090, RTX 3080) and consistently delivers about 2x throughput over baselines on these GPUs (examples: compression/decompression on RTX 3090 ~232.45/405.09 GB/s and on RTX 3080 ~180.94/329.62 GB/s for tested field)

Outlier-FLE is most effective when data blocks exhibit local smoothness with occasional outlier first elements; for blocks without such outliers Plain-FLE yields similar ratios and may be preferred for maximum throughput
Many HPC datasets exhibit local spatial smoothness that produces small quantization integer differences and occasional outliers, enabling fixed-length and outlier-aware encoding gains

Conclusion: The combination of single-kernel pure-GPU execution, outlier fixed-length encoding, vectorized/coalesced memory accesses, and decoupled-lookback prefix-sum enables CUSZP2 to deliver extreme end-to-end throughput, high memory bandwidth utilization, improved compression ratios, random access, double-precision support, and compatibility across NVIDIA GPUs
